As noticed in HELP-25966, when a deployment is using the [Host Mappings alias|https://docs.opsmanager.mongodb.com/current/tutorial/nav/host-mappings/#aliases] feature, process CPU metrics are not reported. This results in an empty chart. We fail to report process cpu metrics in this situation because in order to collect metrics, we first run a check to see if the connection's hostname-port matches the process's [here|https://github.com/10gen/mms-automation/blob/49fff48b393fd2ac5a318313694e20577f5f48e2/go_planner/src/com.tengen/cm/metrics/processcpu/processcpu.go#L53-L56]. In addition to checking {{process.MonitoringHostPort}}, we want to check if {{connParams.HostPort}} matches the alias. 

The above check was added as part of CLOUDP-36835. Be sure to verify that adding this check does not impact the issue fixed in CLOUDP-36835.

jiraIssues.summary: Fix the race condition when finishing up/ starting up a clustershot
jiraIssues.description:
I think there was a *race condition* in the linked HELP ticket and here were the flow of operations that led to this issue:
 - Lets say we have a a cluster with Shards A-Z
 - The very last shard, shard Z, tries to finalize the current WTC Custershot.
 - Shard Z takes a while to update the next snapshot timestamp AND remove it's cursor description timestamp AFTER removing the topology document.
 - In the meantime other shards does their usual config calls to find out that it's time for clustershot again (from the previous next snapshot timestamp) and one the shards creates a new topology document because of it.
 - Then They all (Shards A - Y) posts their descriptions
 - Then They all (Shards A - Y) call finalize file list endpoint to extend their timestamp, since all the shards at this time has their backup cursor descriptions in the DB the next clustershot continues...

 - NOW the Shard Z is done finishing up on the previous clustershot and REMOVES it's own cursor description and mark the clustershot as complete.
 - When the Shard Z's agent does config call OM finds that there is a topology document and create a checkpoint.next view for the agent to start taking snapshot BUT BUT it sees that there is an incomplete clustershot ( the new one ) with No description from shard Z so it sets the checkpointing.next to null for this shard thinking that this shard still needs to send the description.

 - THis last shard-z keep calling the config endpoint keep getting back null checkpoints and hence shard Z never finishes and hence the clustershot never finishes.

 

 

 

Please investigate if this scenario could happen and fix it as well.

jiraIssues.summary: Make server side admin settings validation same as UI
jiraIssues.description:
Today there is a mismatch/gap in validation that happens on UI vs server when setting app settings. This task will port over any missing validation that happens on the UI, on server as well.

*Why this change?*
We are introduce a new public admin settings API. If we add these validations later in the future, that will be a backwards incompatible change for our customer's deployments. Therefore doing this effort as part of the admin settings API effort.

additionalMetadata.release_notes:
This change introduces new server side validations on a limited set of app settings documented below. 

Important Note: If customers have invalid values for these settings they may start noticing ops manager bootstrap failures due to pre-flight checks. This is intentional for failing fast and have customers fix these values rather than having some abrupt failure thrown later in the code which uses that app settings.

List of configuration validations:
1. "mms.https.ClientCertificateMode":  If present, value must be one of "none", "agents_only", "required"
2. When LDAP Authentication configured:
  * "mms.ldap.url": must be a URL starting with ldap:// or ldaps:// 
  * "mms.ldap.referral": when set, must be one of "follow" or "ignore"
3. When SAML Authentication configured:
  * "mms.saml.idp.uri": must not be blank
  * "mms.saml.sso.url": must not be blank
  * "mms.saml.x509.cert": must not be blank
  * "mms.saml.global.role.owner": must not be blank
  * "mms.saml.user.firstName": must not be blank
  * "mms.saml.user.lastName": must not be blank
  * "mms.saml.user.email": must not be blank
  * "mms.saml.group.member": must not be blank
  * "mms.saml.signature.algorithm": when set, must be one of the following
    * "http://www.w3.org/2000/09/xmldsig#rsa-sha1"
    * "http://www.w3.org/2000/09/xmldsig#dsa-sha1"
    * "http://www.w3.org/2001/04/xmldsig-more#rsa-sha256"
    * "http://www.w3.org/2001/04/xmldsig-more#rsa-sha384"
    * "http://www.w3.org/2001/04/xmldsig-more#rsa-sha512"
4. "brs.queryable.lruCacheCapacityMB": when set, must be a positive integer
5. "mms.alerts.ReplicaSetAlertCheck.maximumPingAgeMinutes": when set, must be a positive integer
6. Any configuration that begins with "mms.featureFlag" must be one of "enabled", "controlled", "disabled"

jiraIssues.summary: Avoid minor releases being the recommended version
jiraIssues.description:
We need to avoid recommending that customers use minor releases.

Here's some context: The release notes for OM introduction of 8.2 support need tweaking a little, but are going to say something along the lines of:
{quote} * Enables MongoDB Server 8.2 for production use for MongoDB deployments managed by Ops Manager 8.0 but is NOT supported for Ops Manager 8.0 backing databases, including AppDB.
 ** This minor release provides early access to *new features and improvements* ahead of the next Long Term Support (LTS) version.
 ** Minor releases like 8.2 are *not LTS* and follow a ~6-month release cadence. To receive ongoing bug and security fixes, you *must stay on the LTS version or upgrade to the latest available minor release*. Patches are not backported to previous minor versions (e.g., once 8.3 is released, 8.2 will no longer receive patches).
 ** Choosing the minor release path requires a commitment to performing *sequential upgrades* through each subsequent release. Skipping minor versions is not supported when upgrading.
 ** Upgrading to a new minor version requires updating the *Feature Compatibility Version (FCV)*, which is a critical step in the upgrade process, and adheres to the same upgrade logic as a [major version upgrade|https://www.mongodb.com/docs/ops-manager/current/tutorial/change-mongodb-version/].
 ** You have a *grace period of 2 months* after the next release is available to complete your upgrade and remain supported.{quote}

Unfortunately, we don't have general docs to cover minor releases universally. 

 

But what I think we ought to do is:
 # Ensure that only the latest major version patch (e.g. 8.0.x) shows up as the default selection for use.
 # If a minor version is selected, show a warning of:

{quote}_*Caution:*_ *You are selecting a non-LTS (Minor) release.*

Minor releases (e.g., 8.2) give you access to new server features sooner, but they have a rapid, ~6-month support cycle.

Please review the following support considerations before proceeding:
 # *No Backported Fixes* To receive ongoing bug and security patches, you *must* upgrade to the latest minor release. Once the next version (e.g., 8.3) is out, previous versions ( e.g., 8.2) *will no longer receive updates*.
 # *Sequential Upgrades Required* Once on this path, you *cannot skip* versions. To get from 8.2 to 9.0, you must upgrade sequentially through every subsequent minor release (e.g., 8.2 → 8.3 → ... → 9.0).
 # *FCV Upgrade Required* Each minor version upgrade requires an FCV (Feature Compatibility Version) change. This is a significant operation, [similar to a major version upgrade|https://www.mongodb.com/docs/ops-manager/current/tutorial/change-mongodb-version/], and impacts your ability to downgrade.
 # *Support Grace Period* You have a 2-month grace period to complete your upgrade after the next release becomes available.{quote}

Not sure how we should convey this in the API??!

customGuidelines:
Ops Manager release style:
- Improvements must start with version upgrade bullets in this order: MongoDB Agent, MongoDB Connector for BI, MongoDB Database Tools, JDK.
- Each upgrade bullet must use the exact wording below, replace <VERSION> with backticked numbers, and include every supporting Jira issue key in the citations array:
  - Updates the MongoDB Agent to `<VERSION>`.
  - Adds support for MongoDB Connector for BI `<VERSION>`.
  - Supports MongoDB Database Tools `<VERSION>`.
  - Updates JDK to `<VERSION>`.
- Add a links entry for each upgrade bullet using the same product name or version as link text and these URL templates:
  - MongoDB Agent → https://www.mongodb.com/docs/ops-manager/current/release-notes/mongodb-agent/#std-label-mongodb-<VERSION>
  - MongoDB Connector for BI → https://www.mongodb.com/docs/bi-connector/current/
  - MongoDB Database Tools → https://www.mongodb.com/docs/database-tools/release-notes/database-tools-changelog/#std-label-dbtools-<VERSION>-changelog
  - JDK → https://adoptium.net/temurin/release-notes/?version=<VERSION>
- After those upgrades, list the remaining Improvements items as single-sentence, user-facing bullets and include every applicable Jira key in the citations array.
- Bug Fixes should list regular fixes first. If any vulnerabilities exist, finish with a parent bullet titled "Fixes the following CVEs:" that has no citations.
- Under that parent, add one sub-bullet per CVE, cite its Jira issue, and include a links entry at https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/<CVE_ID>.
- Wrap tokens users might copy (versions, package names, CLI commands, config keys) in single backticks.
- Use subitems only when they provide extra guidance beyond the main bullet.
